camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z29
camera.description: 10.1 million effective pixels; 41 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 37.5 mm - 112.5 mm (2.9x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: Basic entry-level compact with 10.1 megapixel sensor, 2.7-inch LCD and 3x optical zoo (covering a rather uninsipiring 37.5-112.5mm range). Slim and stylish all-mteal design - plus lots of beginner-friendly features and widescreen video option - provide some appeal, but as with all cameras at this end of the market it struggles to stand out from the crowd. (April 2009)

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z85

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z9

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z80
camera.description: 8.1 million effective pixels; 33 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 38 mm - 114 mm (3x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: Budget model from the over-populated Exilim range offers the extensive range of gadgets and gizmos we've come to expect from Casio but sticks to the basics when it comes to the important stuff, offering a pedestrian 3x zoom lens and, like most entry-point models, a low resolution screen. Has a smarter, slimmer design than most in this category, but the price is far from the lowest. (April 2009)

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z100
camera.description: 10.1 million effective pixels; 35 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 28 mm - 112 mm (4x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: Casio's first foray into wide angle lenses on its ultra compact cameras came in the shape of the EX-Z100 and sister model the EX-Z200 (which adds CCD-shift image stabilization) - though they have since been joined by several other models in the ever-expanding Exilim Zoom range. The 28-112mm (equiv.) 4x zoom is far more useful than the 3x version used on most of Casio's super slim models, and the ability to shoot widescreen movies in the efficient H.264 format is welcome. Otherwise it's pretty standard stuff, with Casio's usual overabundance of BESTSHOT scene modes (39 in total) and a tiny 10 megapixel sensor. (April 2009)

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-S10
camera.description: 10.1 million effective pixels; 35 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 36 mm - 108 mm (3x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: The Casio EX-S10 was, at the time of launch in January '08, the world's slimmest digital camera - a crown Casio seems loathe to relinquish. Into its tiny body the S10 manages to fit a variety of the latest consumer-friendly features including a series of automatic shutter modes - smile shutter, panning detection and blur minimization. It also includes the YouTube movie capture mode that Casio pioneered in its recent compacts. Unfortunately the camera is a lot more impressive than the results it produces, which are marred by unreliable auto focus and exposure systems and - for a camera so obviously aimed at the social user - the flash performance is disappointing. (April 2009)

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z200
camera.description: 10.1 million effective pixels; 35 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 28 mm - 112 mm (4x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: Casio's first foray into wide angle lenses on its ultra compact cameras came in the shape of the EX-Z200 and sister model the EX-Z100 (which is loses the CCD-shift image stabilization but is otherwise identical) - though they have since been joined by several other models in the ever-expanding Exilim Zoom range. The 28-112mm (equiv.) 4x zoom is far more useful than the 3x version used on most of Casio's super slim models, and the ability to shoot widescreen movies in the efficient H.264 format is welcome. Otherwise it's pretty standard stuff, with Casio's usual overabundance of BESTSHOT scene modes (39 in total) and a tiny 10 megapixel sensor. (April 2009)

camera.name: Casio Exilim Pro EX-F1
camera.description: 6.0 million effective pixels; 16 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 36 mm - 432 mm (12x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: Boasting the world's fastest burst shooting (up to 60 frames per second) and movie capture at up to 1200 fps, the EX-F1 has developed something of a cult following thanks to its ability to produce the kind of slow-motion footage that once required specialized equipment. The SLR-like styling and 36-432mm (equiv.) 12x zoom are pretty standard fare and the 6MP stills are far from class-leading, but the ability to shoot 1080P movies, the ultra high speed shooting modes and the extensive feature set will undoubtedly appeal to the gadget lover wanting something a little different. Unfortunately no matter how appealing the slow-mo movies, the price - around $1000 at launch - is going to be hard for many to justify, especially with the launch of the EX-FH20, which has a better mix of features and a far more appealing price. (April 2009).

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z1050

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-Z75
camera.description: 7.1 million effective pixels; 29 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 38 mm - 114 mm (3x) zoom lens;

camera.name: Casio Exilim EX-V7
camera.description: 7.1 million effective pixels; 29 MP/cm^2 pixel density; 38 mm - 266 mm (7x) zoom lens;
camera.summary: The Casio EX-V7 is one of the those cameras that works better on paper than it does 'in the flesh'. The combination of ultra-compact design, 7x zoom, mechanical stabilization and rich feature set is an alluring one, and one that makes the EX-V7 one of the most powerful 'pocket cameras' we've seen to date - a real case of 'having your cake a eating it'. The reality is that the EX-V7 is a disappointing camera, and one that fails to deliver on its promise, even allowing for the compromises inevitably involved in squeezing this much stuff into such a small body.
